subject: Law
title: The Fifth Amendment: Right to Silence
description: A 60-second lesson on The Fifth Amendment: Right to Silence.

hook.text: A suspect sat in an interrogation room for hours. When he finally asked for a lawyer, police kept questioning him.

buildup.text: The Fifth Amendment says no person 'shall be compelled to be a witness against himself.'

discovery.text: Miranda v. Arizona (1966) required police to inform suspects of their rights before custodial interrogation.

twist.text: But Miranda rights must be invoked clearly. Staying silent alone isn't enoughâ€”you must say 'I want a lawyer.'

climax.text: Courts have narrowed Miranda over time, but it remains a cornerstone of criminal procedure.

punchline.text: You have the right to remain silent. Use it wisely.

quiz.question: Which case established the Miranda warning requirement?
